Okay, boss, real talk time!  Its an exceptional game, with exceptional effort put into exceptional gameplay, with an underwhelmingly and almost saddeningly small community that is (despite what too many people say) somewhat xenophobic, however its not hard to blend well even if you're new/bad.  Obvious outstanding Pros: +Awesome sord-fitan +Cool, somewhat unique character roster, each having their own moveset +Community content can be enabled in settings, allowing you to see someone elses workshop weapon! (Honestly best!) +Legitimately skillful (supposing you dont have higher than 60 ms ping) gameplay revolving around your reaction times, planning, strategy, and ability to think on your fingers. +Custom servers with unique content enabled change the design of the game, lowgrav makes aircombos (with some ground stances) available midair, creating more intricate and unique ways of play, though lowgrav is dead now. +Character combos are honestly as depthy as it can get, and unless you're fighting a one trick pony, you will need to adapt and switch into different tactics to win the fight, I garuntee it, boss!  The sad cons, that we should all understand are NOT REALLY THE DEVELOPER'S FAULT  -It sometimes feels like you might be the one and only person who plays this game. -If you are easily stressed/find yourself mad a lot, this game will make you angry. You will lose a lot, it is to be expected. -Weapon types are somewhat lacking, and should change more than just damage values, interval rates, and such. I always feel as though the katana is useless, scimitar is hyper situational, Jian is for pure, and only longsword/rapier work out in the end for stable gameplay. If you're like me and you fashion souls, you wont worry, and will just have a beautiful tool swinging at those nasty little runts! -Perhaps a hidden ranking system, or the ability to not show your rank on some servers. Its jarring when you're oak/iron, and all you see is masters, because you dont want to lose, its a possible reason why our community is so small. -Community is TINY. Even on our recent peaks, we will only see around 100 people at most on servers, whereas mostly its 20-10, its that bad. However, whoever is there is strangely always someone different. -Any lag whatsoever kills the fidelity of the game, on either end. No matter which side is lagging, you're going to lose, because for some reason, this game cannot handle even the minutest change in ping, you will notice that your parries are useless, your gaurd always broken, your back always being stabbed, ranged always hitting, lights parrying balanced, and worst of all, they will almost always disappear when you swing. Its bad, its so bad, but its source, and thats source's horrid issue, best you can do is hope to lead where they're going and always use light/air to keep quick.  Some nitpicky issues now. -Characters are all asian, its the game's design style, but its just edgy and silly, boss. -(Weapon) feels weak unless used on (character), every type, every character.  -Weapons should be better diversified, and the ability to possibly use a customized, point based weapon type with the only change being a skin might actually seem better than the current system. For example...  --- Lets say, you just want to make a sword thats good for comboing. You have around 100 points to spam into various attributes, those attributes could be divided into some divisions like  Base damage Side damage Air damage Combo interval Combo speed Can guard/(whatever rapier's gaurd is)/Feint/no gaurd (for increased points or easier charge) Charge speed/damage mods  While veterans of the community are K with what we have, this change would bring more uniquity to the gameplay as less cut and paste styles would be present. We're looking at you, JianPure/ScimitarPhalanx.  Imagine if you could make a multihit wrecking sword for disorienting and winning through attrition, or a TRUE CHAOS FLAME +5 ZWEIHANDER FOR MAXIMUM BASE CANNON! Or a faster swinging but weaker hitting wep to make Ryoku actually viable and not countered by moving left slightly. ... Or we could just have less cut and paste weapon types.  It might even be a rad idea, to do something like this with characters, mixing and matching combo patterns to weave your own intricate web of butt-touchingly awesome combos that will make everyone on the server mad! --- Overall, its a great game, boss! But it has its flaws, and they can get a little jarring if you're not very prepared to face them. I think if more people played it, more love would be seen all around, while I would prefer to see the game change drastically, most people don't and are comfortable with what we have, but I feel that appropriate changes would see a more unique crowd enter to join in on our fun.  Its a 9/10 game with a 11/10 community, funny goodhearted people, though few as they be.  Now get the heck out of my inn, boss!

Weapons duelers like Chivalry and Soul Calibur are based around using different types of weapons with different skillsets like hammers, nunchucks, and zweihanders. Blade Symphony takes this concept and narrows it down to just swords, and by doing this, they have a created a skill-based duel game that is fun to watch and play.   Story wise, Blade Symphony isn't much to look at. Here's the gist of it: You're a blind swordsman trying to become the best in the world. Seriously, that's it. However that's not where Blade Symphony shines. It's graphics are very well done, especially at the particles when swords collide. All of the models, both sword and duelist, are very well done with textures fitting the weapons, like giving the katana 'Serrated Serenade' a serrated edge. When wandering around the maps in free for all mode, it's a joy to be able to climb up onto a roof and take in the scenery. While playing I didn't notice any texture pop ins or jagged edges.  While Blade Symphony may be lacking a story, it more than makes up for it with its deep customization and sword play. Upon entering, you're guided through a series of tutorials teaching you about basic things like sword types, all the way up to advanced side cancelling, with Puny Human planning on releasing more as time passes. You'll pick from one of four classes, with Judgement being your defensive tank, Ryoku being the nimble fiighter, Phalanx your long reach sniper, and Pure with her fancy spins and sword flurries. Along with your sword type, either katana, longsword, rapier, scimitar, or jian, and sets of fast, balanced, and heavy stances, you have an unlimited amount of strategies waiting to be learned. You'll see common ones like Judgement with a longsword to deal massive damage, or Phalanx with a rapier to deal bursts of damage, you can visualize more unique ones. A slow and bulky Judgement wielding the jian, which speeds up your move recovery, can help him compensate for his slow heavy attacks. Fighting tooth and nail with another play is electryfing, and the main reason why this game is so much fun to watch. When not slashing other players into bite-sized chunks, you'll be either waiting for the way too long load screens to disappear, or using your currency to purchase new swords and masks. While they certainly change how your character looks, they don't do anything to impede the balance of the game, since everything is cosmetic. This makes the game purely reliant on skill. The only way to get good at the game is to practice, practice, practice.   THE VERDICT:  Stuff I liked: +Simple yet deep swordplay +Vast customization +Skill based gameplay +Electryfing duels  Stuff I didn't like: -Horrendous loading times  9.5/10 Outstanding  With how easy it is to get into Blade Symphony and how deep the strategies go, it's easy to lose several hours into one play session. If you want a multiplayer duel with a large amount of depth and customization that takes a minute to learn and a lifetime to master, stop reading this review and add Blade Symphony to your cart.

I haven't played this game for as much as I'd like to thus far, but it's pretty clear already how impressive it is.  Going through all of the tutorials gave me a grasp on the fighting system works. I understand the basics, but still can not reliably win in a duel for the life of me. This is and of itself isn't a bad thing. In fact, part of me is excited for how much more I have to learn. Unfortunately, another part of me is upset by the fact that there's no easy or convenient way to do so.  This game does not hold your hand. It very much tosses you into the deep end and lets you sink or swim of your own accord. If you've ever played 'Toribash', you'll probably understand what I'm talking about; you've got an incredibly complex fighting system that you can start with a friend to be on-par with (though only because neither of you are any good yet), or you can play against bots or foes online that understands the ins and outs of the system and as such, at least for a reasonable while, tend to beat you without contest.  The game makes a point of saying that it will include further tutorials at a later point, which would certainly be welcome because as it stands one has to figure out most of the mechanics by themselves after seeing somebody else do it. YouTube for now remains the best place for in-depth tutorials to be best of my knowledge. In any case, this is definitely a game that will take a long time to master. If you're genuinely willing to spend many, many hours playing and perfecting this game, then good for you, I recommend it. I fear for many, though, it could end up sitting in their library as âthat one game I really should really get better at some timeâ.  Character customisation is decent â you can chose one of four characters and one of a lot of swords, both affecting gameplay stats, and you can also make a few aesthetic changes. Unfortunately the character and sword you fancy most for the looks mightn't necessarily be the best for actual competition, but I find changing up your style to match a new, cool sword you unlock is refreshing. The modding community is certainly not lacking - there are plenty of custom items and maps to download, if that's your bag.  I tentatively recommend this. I think you can already tell whether or not you'd be wasting your money.

I have been eyeing this game for a while and was fortunate to get it in a bundle.   If you like swordplay, dueling, and heavily-skill based gameplay, then you will enjoy this game.  The aesthetics are fantastic with very detailed models, skins, and weapons. There is strong mod support for user-based content, adding a large variety to the customization potential. The music is very good at keeping you engaged in the extremely intense combat.  Although you will be primarily using the mouse, the controls can be very tricky to master without lots of practice, and the learning curve is moderate to high - depending on whether you are used to aggressive, all-out-offense gameplay (you will find this game very difficult if that is your preferred playstyle). The tutorial is very helpful and critical to understanding the mechanics of the game - playing practice fights with the AI can help you get a grasp of how each character + weapon works. The combos are not complex since you are just moving and using the mouse, but things like timing, switching stances mid combo, parrying, and dodging are important to balance and master.  The feedback for where and how your sword will strike is provided by a faint aura showing the weapon path. Manipulate where you will strike by using the mouse and also by moving around. You can do air attacks by jumping first.   There are different types of weapons, like katanas, longswords, and scimitars. Each weapon has different characteristics - for example: the katana is a fairly advanced weapon, inflicting heavy damage during counterattacks, but weaker in overall regular attacks. The longsword is pretty balanced and has a good blocking move.   You have three different stances, fast, balanced, and heavy - you can switch at will by rolling the mouse wheel. Using these stances, there is a rock-paper-scissors element that becomes integral to survival in this game. When two swords hit at the same time, a parry happens; however, different stances will override the parry, inflicting damage and creating a window for counterattacking. You can switch stances in the middle of your combos, and this makes the game very intense when you are trying to strategize and outmaneuver your opponent.   You can also cancel attacks to feint, and the tutorial does a good job of teaching you how to do this.   In the beginning, when you are first learning to play, be prepared to die. A lot. If you play roguelike games or Demon/Dark Souls, you should be well accustomed to dying - it will be the same here. Even when you are defeating the AI consistently and with excessive ease, you will still die when you play online. Just remember, its all part of the learning process.  I noticed that the connection time can get pretty lengthy, so that is something to consider - there is also no average wait timer, so you can't know for sure how long it will take to find/enter a match. There is also a lot of complaints about the card drop rate - if this is something you care about, I have found this game to have the most ridiculous drop rates. I still have 3 drops left, and others have reported only 1 drop in 8 hours. This isn't too big of a deal if you intend to play this regularly, but definitely be aware.  This game definitely takes a significant amount of skill, and I advise you to stay away if you intend to play casually or do not like games that are too difficult. Otherwise, give it a try, and you may find the challenge to be to your taste.  Recommend.

A well thought out duelling game with the majority of players developing a sense of good will and sportsmanship sparsely seen in many video games today.   Fights generally take place in these 1v1 arenas where players use strings of light, medium and heavy attacks to defeat the opponent. Players can make use of evasive moves and the environment to reposition themselves favourably in combat. Sword strikes themselves are influnced by the direction you're moving in, so clashes occur naturally where swords meet.   The best part of this game is definately the decorum and sportsmanship demonstrated by the community as a whole. You may on occasion be greeted by the one annoying hater, but generally speaking games begin with a bow, and end with 'GG' and showers of praise.  There are only a handful of characters at this point, but lots of customisation and personalisation options, compounded with steam workshop to expand the horizons even further. Right now, I play as Judgement with a TV for a Head and use a stick with a love heart on the end of it.  Last I checked the community was waning and I had difficulty finding players at my skill level to play with, but we shall see following my new PC upgrade!

'My opponent was jumping straight at me, and just when I thought I had him countered, he rewises his trajectory in mid-air, then landing sword first on my poor face. After the match, when I asked him what it was, he answered mystically, 'It's called air canceling'. That got me wondering, so it wasn't cheating or lag, but a trick within the game's rules... After a few minutes in the training room, I realized I could pull off the same move with some practice, though using it in a match... Well, that was another story...' Then I realized something bigger, this game was much like swordfighting or martial arts in itself... The only way to reach the next level is to learn with your (avatar's) body, feeling it all through combat.  But just how do you recommend a game that's a cross between fighting games and third person action? Well, there's just nothing quite like this anywhere. The combat is a mix of 'FPS-twitchiness' and hack-and-slash, combined with hp bars, rounds and move dynamics of your average fighting game.   While weapons differ to a lesser degree, the 4 classes all have a distinct feel to them. But just comparing the diversity of the classes and moves doesn't do this thing right--- There's just so many ways to do battle, spam fast attacks and find yourself countered by a heavier attack (or not if you spaced yourself right). Thought you had it all calculated and fall into an attack cancel, taking a heavy blow to yer face. While the tutorial and basic mechanics feel very barebones, there's just so much to find out on your own, this game would last ages for anyone with even a little competitive spirit.  To top it all off, there's free workshop content for customising your look in any manner you like, crazy anime weaponry, cardboard tubes, ski poles and of course videogame swords. Most of the community is also very helpful and there is a samurai-like code of honour when it comes to dueling. The only downside is that the majority of the remaining population has been playing for months now, meaning that any newbies like yours truly will have their bottoms handsomely handed to themselves.

Do you like fighting games?  This isn't one.  Sure, two players enter an arena and attempt to beat the crap out of each other, best 2 out of 3 wins. If that's the only way you define fighting game, then go ahead and call it one.  BUT  Blade Symphony is lacking in the depth present in a game like Skullgirls or Street Fighter. It's less about knowing what your opponent will try and more about exploiting the game itself to gain an advantage.  The third person over-the-should view obfusicates much of your ability to gauge the actual range of your own attacks, as well as those of your opponent. Hit detection is often quite spotty. Which results in awkward advances followed by swinging wildly while backing up. Hit and run tactics are the way this game is played for the most part.  Blade Symphony lacks the consistency of fighting games too. Frame rates aren't consistent, so good luck trying to gracefully and skillfully link sword attacks into one another. What you'll really end up doing is clicking and wildly swinging your camera around to manipulate your attack's path and speed.  It doesn't have the careful balance of fighting games, either. The project's leader, Flux, set out to initially balance the attacks each character possesses using a very simple method. He played against the 'knight' character, who for the purpose of this process used only his slowest, strongest attack. Clicking over and over, using only this attack, Flux then played each character and gave them tools to counter or get around this attack.  Then he was done balancing. The characters were done being iterated on, for the most part.  The dev team tweaks the numbers, at this point - sword swing speeds, damage values etc, but the ongoing balance meetings really only involve Flux asking the 'top players' (read: most popular/vocal at the top of the leaderboard) what should be done. And of course, you can imagine the clamoring for the weakening of characters that they have trouble with, and the buffing of their mains. To be fair, it's not really the player's fault - it's natural and unavoidable to be biased in your own favor, no matter how impartial you think you are. The blame lies with the devs for outsourcing it's finer balance decisions to the most highly competetive players.  Several characters have attacks that are so fast, they actually exceed the game's ability to display and often detect. Which can have wildly inconsistent results.  This game plays more like a third person action game, or an extremely bare-bones character action game. That's multiplayer only. Very little realism to be had, with characters defying physics with certain attacks, outlandish Errol Flynn techniques, and in some cases outright flying.  If you can look past some very bizzare balancing philosophies (ie none at all) and don't expect to play more than one character (ie the one everyone at the top of the leaderboard plays) then you might enjoy this as a unique competetive experience. But all I can see is a whole lot of potential wasted by poor decisionmaking and direction.

Now factor in that these attacks are modified by directional movement, and every character has different attack patterns for three different stances. How the hell is the player supposed to get this under control? Hit detection feels really strange on top of that, and the game gives you very little feedback to indicate what's happening.   As a result, fights feel like a bunch of spamming that has your characters flying all over the place, and you just hope that you're going to connect with something before the other person does. Not a very satisfying combat system, and the combat system is the entire game.  I'm sure it could get interesting between people who have spent hundreds of hours memorizing the attack patterns of various character/weapon combinations, to have some chance of matching them effectively, but I'm definitely not the type who cares to do that.  I understand that it's early access, and I'll give it a chance when closer to a finished product. Sadly, I'm not expecting much. They need to deeply rework the basic functioning of their combat system to be playable, in my opinion.
